question: The leadership team and board are completely aligned on the value creation plan (maps out the core drivers of value creation).
Employees at all levels clearly understand the company's strategic plan.
The strategic plan is reviewed and refreshed annually to ensure relevance and alignment.
A comprehensive communication plan has been used to share the strategic plan and annual goals.
The purpose (mission), vision and values (all three) are clearly understood by employees.
The customer value proposition is clearly defined. (The value proposition defines how to gain or retain a competitive advantage.)
The business model is clearly defined (an integrated set of choices made by the company that are unique relative to competitors).
The leadership team is aligned on the current stage of the business (early, growth, mature, declining) and near-term opportunities and threats.
A brand growth strategy with clear growth drivers has been defined (this explicitly defines how to grow revenue / market share by ensuring the brand matches a specific customer need).
The market has been thoroughly analyzed (size, segments, growth rates, level of maturity and key risks/opportunities for the core business).
The competitive landscape has been thoroughly analyzed (core competitors, emerging competitors, share shifts, what will win and who will win).
The leadership team meets at least once per quarter to review the competitive landscape and assess internal performance.
The organization is encouraged to share and discuss competitive information proactively.
The value creation plan has been translated into a 3-5 year strategic plan for the business (detailed roadmap that aligns key initiatives, financial targets, and execution timelines).
The organization has a clearly defined Innovation Strategy (this provides context for which investments to pursue, and which to not pursue).
The leadership team has established a clear innovation agenda (what focus areas to investigate and explore).
The strategy is evaluated to inform the annual planning process.
Organizational culture (values, beliefs, and behaviors expected of its members) is explicitly defined.
A clear digital/technology strategy exists (articulates what technology capabilities you need to achieve your strategic ambitions and how to accomplish it).
A clearly defined capital allocation/investment strategy exists (articulates how capital will be allocated to long-term value creation across different uses and opportunities).
The budget is sufficient to achieve the initiatives outlined in the strategic plan.
Company initiatives directly link to achieving the strategic plan and are clearly defined.
The leadership team has defined the metrics it should be measuring to track progress toward strategic goals.
Progress against initiatives is transparently tracked by the leadership team and actively discussed.
The business receives routine, timely, accurate, and actionable information for decision making.
Efficient decision-making is a priority and documented processes expedite discussions and approvals.
All meetings have clear agendas with appropriate participants and action items.
The organization efficiently allocates resources (time, people, and financial resources) according to strategic priorities.
Department KPIs align with the organization's annual and multi-year plans.
Employees clearly understand their objectives and how they link to company initiatives and strategy.
Processes, systems, and structure have been clearly articulated and are consistently followed.
Transparency is valued in the organization and extends to both positive and negative events.
The organization regularly evaluates the effectiveness of its processes, systems, and structure.
Annual organizational goals are established for all leaders and regularly progress is tracked.
The leadership team, managers, and employees provide open, constructive feedback on process inefficiencies, redundancies, or gaps.
The leadership team uses multi-year functional plans to determine capabilities needed to execute the strategic plan.
The leadership team has the functional expertise, commercial acumen and business knowledge needed to execute the strategy.
There are significant cross-training opportunities to develop employees, especially for key roles.
Succession plans are in place for key leadership positions and are regularly reviewed.
High-potential talent is identified, and development plans are formalized and regularly reviewed for progress.
The organization provides access to high quality development opportunities.
The company regularly calibrates and takes action to ensure employees are in roles that align with their skills, experience, and career ambitions.
Functional and leadership development is prioritized for organizational growth.
The organization is able to quickly redeploy resources where needed.
Regular, collective reviews of growth and potential ensure consistent talent assessment.
Key functions are appropriately set up for their current maturity level.
Core functions are appropriately sized and staffed for the current business stage.
There is a dedicated team focused on implementing new ideas and business ventures.
The organization has the capabilities required to implement and carry out the enterprise-wide innovation strategy.
The leadership team has assessed which structures (centralized, dispersed, hybrid), processes, and cultural enablers will support innovation initiatives.
The organization regularly evaluates the success of its investment strategy in innovation (e.g., ROI of initiatives, actual vs. expected results).
The organization regularly evaluates the external market for M&A and partnership opportunities to expand strategic capabilities.
The organization conducts regular and rigorous evaluations of potential M&A and partnership opportunities against established criteria.
The organization takes the time to properly integrate M&A and partnership opportunities.
The scope, nature and complexity of the work remains challenging enough to encourage high performance.
Employees at all levels of the organization understand how to leverage innovation in their roles.
The organization actively encourages employees to present innovative ideas.
Regular and honest customer feedback on performance is gathered and incorporated into the strategic plan.
Discussions regarding priorities, strategic initiatives and common goals occur regularly across functions.
The organization regularly evaluates and tracks engagement across the company and uses the data/feedback to take action to improve culture.
The organization regularly benchmarks against external companies for pay equity, job leveling, and organizational design effectiveness.
The organization has a system for identifying, developing, and reinforcing high-quality hires.
Leader and employee development programs enable identification of individual needs and evaluation of overall quality.
The organization actively and continually seeks data to make informed decisions.
There is an expectation for employees to give and receive constructive feedback (up, down and across the organization).
